image.altText: Toxic chemical symbols super-imposed on an a photo of a cotton bulb.

props.synopsis: A cotton industry advocate says dryland crops are at risk if the regulator lowers the usage rate of a chemical that has been linked to Parkinson's disease.

title.children: Australia's cotton industry says it is safe to keep using controversial chemical paraquat

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese Blue Room

props.synopsis: The prime minister says he only remembers limited interactions with former Qantas boss Alan Joyce, and if there are specific claims he made direct calls to ask for free upgrades, "let them be made".

title.children: Albanese attacks claims he requested free flight upgrades from Qantas boss as rumours 'to sell a book'

image.altText: Person sitting on a couch working on a laptop

props.synopsis: A tribunal finds a council employee who tripped over a 60-centimetre pet fence during a coffee break while working from home is entitled to workers compensation.

title.children: Council employee who tripped over pet fence while working from home wins compensation claim

image.altText: Terrence Alick reading from the Atlas of Queensland and Northern Territory Pastoral Stations

props.synopsis: Their work has been a godsend for the directionally challenged and a staple in the homes and cars of farmers, graziers and rural Australians everywhere, but Terrence and Rosemary Alick are about to call it a day.

title.children: Authors of outback atlas credited with saving lives retiring after 35 years

image.altText: a man in a wheelchair with his arm around a woman inside a sports centre

props.synopsis: Daniel Forssman's life changed forever when a motorbike crash left him paralysed. He's set himself an ambitious goal: to make it to the Paralympic Games.

title.children: A talent search for Australia's future Paralympians offers hope for aspiring athletes

image.altText: Te back of a burnt cross in a cemetery

props.synopsis: Police in Fitzroy Crossing in Western Australia's north say the burn is the result of a bushfire and the local shire has promised to ramp up efforts to protect the area.

title.children: Relatives discover loved ones' graves burnt after bushfire

image.altText: The exterior of the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre, with barbed wire in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A brand new Northern Territory youth detention facility is about to open and accept detainees in Darwin in order to free up beds for adult prisoners at Don Dale Youth Detention Centre.

title.children: NT government soon to move children from Don Dale detention centre to new youth prison

image.altText: A barbed wire fence with a security camera in the background

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory government says it is urgently working to address the "extraordinary risks" posed by record prison overcrowding. But the union representing prison guards fears it won't be enough to improve conditions.

title.children: NT prison guards consider industrial action over record high prisoner numbers

image.altText: a block of white flats surrounded by tropical foliage

props.synopsis: A murder trial has begun in Darwin more than two years after a 54-year-old man died from injuries allegedly sustained during a violent assault.

title.children: Man faces trial for alleged murder of cousin in Darwin CBD unit

image.altText: Jack Lawrence, wearing a grey 'Trump 2024' t-shirt and red 'Make America Great Again' cap, stands near a queue of people outside

props.synopsis: Donald Trump is working to get a notoriously unreliable voting bloc — young men — off the couch and into the polling booths. There's evidence his strategy is working.

title.children: Some young American men want Trump to 'bring back the masculine face you saw in the 60s'

image.altText: An older man in a red shirt standing in front of a tree

props.synopsis: When spraying crops, John O'Brien would end up covered in chemicals including paraquat. He's one of six farmers from Crookwell who say they have been diagnosed with Parkinson's Disease.

title.children: Six farmers grew up in the same tiny town getting 'covered' in chemicals. They all now have Parkinson's

image.altText: Sean 'Diddy' Combs

props.synopsis: The California plaintiff accuses the music mogul of spiking his drink and forcing him to perform oral sex after the then-10-year-old said he would "do anything" to become a star.

title.children: Sean 'Diddy' Combs accused of drugging and sexually assaulting 10-year-old boy during 'audition'

image.altText: the premier looking away from the camera

props.synopsis: David Crisafulli, Queensland's new premier, ran a troubled training organisation when it tried and failed to convince regulators that breaches of compliance rules had been fixed.

title.children: FOI documents reveal federal regulator personally wrote to Queensland's new premier over troubled training organisation

image.altText: Two signes outside a shop that read "MYER"

props.synopsis: Department store giant Myer will purchase a slew of fashion chains, giving it ownership of nearly 800 retail stores across Australia and New Zealand.

title.children: Myer buys more than 700 fashion stores, including Just Jeans, Portmans and Jay Jays

image.altText: A brunette woman stands in the street holding a cup of ice cream. She wears a white tank top and denim skirt.

props.synopsis: Egg freezing is often sold by fertility clinics as an "insurance policy". But some experts say it's more like a lottery, and few women return to use their frozen eggs.

title.children: Freezing eggs is sold as an 'insurance policy', but few women go on to use them

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios looks up

props.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios says he 'could come back now and beat 50 per cent of players' if he wanted to, but that his fans deserve more.

title.children: 'I could come back now and beat 50 per cent of players': Kyrgios opens up on tennis comeback plans

image.altText: Two beef cattle

props.synopsis: Many Australian farmers are getting squeezed at "both ends" by concentrated markets.

title.children: Australia's small-scale farmers are 'meat in a market concentration sandwich'

image.altText: Riddoch Highway sign shows directional pointers to Penola, Mt Gambier, Keith and Naracoorte

props.synopsis: A 15-year-old girl has become the second person to die in a three-car smash in South Australia's south-east. The teenager and a five-year-old boy, who died at the scene on Sunday, were passengers in a car that was rear-ended.

title.children: Second child dies after three-car crash involving emu

image.altText: Three women stir large pots of curry, as they prepare lunch at the Sikh Temple in Woolgoolga.

props.synopsis: On New South Wales' Mid North Coast, a town boasts a population where 25 per cent is of Indian heritage. Originally settling for agricultural opportunities, there is a deeper reason the Punjabi Sikhs stay in Woolgoolga.

title.children: The migration of the Punjabi Sikhs of Woolgoolga, and what keeps them in town

image.altText: Jan Brueghel ridden by Dean Gallagher

props.synopsis: Irish raider Jan Brueghel, one of the pre-race favourites for next Tuesday's Melbourne Cup, has been withdrawn from the race after veterinary advice.

title.children: Irish raider out of Melbourne Cup after veterinary advice

image.altText: Kyra Cooney-Cross launches the ball towards goal

props.synopsis: The Matildas have come from behind to beat Germany 2-1 in Duisburg thanks to maiden international goals from Kyra Cooney-Cross and Clare Hunt.

title.children: 'One of the great goals' from Kyra Cooney-Cross hands Matildas dramatic victory against Germany

image.altText: photo portrait of Bernard Fanning in a grey suit and open red shirt

props.synopsis: He's the frontman of one of Australia's biggest bands, and the only singer to have topped triple j's Hottest 100 three times. But Powderfinger's Bernard Fanning has always had self doubt and, as he tells Zan Rowe on Take 5, almost gave up on a music career entirely.

title.children: Powderfinger were one of Australia's biggest bands. But frontman Bernard Fanning felt like an imposter

image.altText: A woman with long black hair stands in front of a microphone looking serious.

props.synopsis: Former leader Jeremy Hanson is challenging Ms Lee for the top spot.

title.children: 'I'm the best person': Elizabeth Lee to recontest Canberra Liberals leadership

image.altText: A farmer on a tractor moving on a field of dirt with mountains in the distance

props.synopsis: Farming and aid groups are warning the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah could affect food supplies in Lebanon and Syria and push hundreds of thousands of people into long-term poverty.

title.children: Olive oil, bananas and avocado: How Israel and Hezbollah's deadly war is impacting much-needed food supplies

image.altText: A data centre containing rows of computer equipment.

props.synopsis: Huge data centres built for generative AI will generate millions of tonnes of electronic waste by 2030, the equivalent of discarding billions of smartphones each year, a study suggests.

title.children: Massive new AI data centres will generate millions of tonnes of electronic waste

image.altText: Just Jeans store in Melbourne

props.synopsis: Department store Myer strikes a deal for Premier Investment's clothing brands, and investors in Premier cheer the news. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX rises, Premier rallies on Just Jeans, Dotti deal

image.altText: A burnt out battery.

props.synopsis: Australia's annual lithium-ion battery waste is tipped to hit 137,000 tonnes by 2035, and with 90 per cent of current waste going into landfill or getting stockpiled, there are urgent calls for dedicated recycling facilities.

title.children: Lithium-ion recycling facilities 'urgently' needed as toxic waste soars in Australia

image.altText: A dimly lit pokies room with bright colourful lights coming from each of the machines.

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says pokies companies' use of tax credits designed to promote innovation is "problematic".

title.children: Pokies, pizza and precision weapons companies all eligible for innovation tax credits

image.altText: Moody image of a person dressed in dark work clothes

props.synopsis: Preliminary results of a global survey show Australia has some of the highest rates of work addiction. Managers, people with a demanding job and those with family members addicted to work are at the highest risk of developing a work addiction.

title.children: A quarter of Australians are addicted to work, preliminary research finds

image.altText: A woman holds and looks down at a baby onesie while standing in a room.

props.synopsis: Nicky has been living in a two-bedroom motel with her children after rental demand skyrocketed in south-east Queensland.

title.children: Pregnant mother with 'guaranteed income' left homeless after almost 100 unsuccessful rental applications

image.altText: Saltmarsh driver 4

props.synopsis: These saltmarshes entice many people in for a 4WD adventure, but motorists are destroying the "underrated heroes" of the Great Barrier Reef ecosystem.

title.children: Drivers tear up saltmarshes at popular Queensland tourism spot, damaging sensitive and vital ecosystem

image.altText: Former President Rodrigo Duterte pointing his right hand at someone out of frame. He is wearing a white shirt.

props.synopsis: He admitted to using "gangsters" to kill other criminals while mayor of Davao, but denied ordering the killing of thousands under his crackdown on drugs while president.

title.children: Rodrigo Duterte says he kept a 'death squad' as mayor to kill criminals

image.altText: Yvonne Strahovski and Caleb Dolden in Teacup

props.synopsis: Body horror meets family drama in Teacup, Australian filmmaker James Wan's latest project starring fellow Aussie Yvonne Strahovski.

title.children: Teacup is a slightly silly horror TV show and the perfect comfort watch
